Book an appointment to see your GP, taking sick leave from work.

questions:

You are having difficulty driving to work and walking long distances due to pain. You are on the rota to work long shifts all week.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes: In this scenario your personal health should take priority over your work commitments. The correct course of action is to book an appointment with your GP (whether in person or via the telephone). Although misuse of the Emergency Department system should be avoided, it is preferable to taking medicines from work or putting your colleague in the difficult position of prescribing for you.

questions:
You are a F2 working in the Cardiology Unit. You have mandatory F2 teaching once a month which all F2's are required to attend. You notice a fellow F2 signing in for the teaching sessions but leaving after 30 minutes. You have seen him do this a few times.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
The correct options are 3, 6 and 7. It is always best to speak to your colleague about your observations (option 3). Attending teaching is an important part of Foundation Training. Missing teaching sessions and falsifying attendance is unprofessional and can warrant disciplinary action. Therefore, explain to your colleague the importance of attending teaching sessions (option 7). If this fails, speaking to your supervisor for advice is sensible (option 6).

Bribing a colleague is unethical (option 5). Telling on a colleague is likely to cause friction and is unnecessary at this stage (option 8). Offering your colleague teaching on the topics you have learnt during teaching may be a kind gesture but could encourage them to miss more sessions in the future (option 4). Following their lead and missing teaching is unprofessional and could risk you getting in to trouble (option 2).

As part of the GMC's Good Medical Practice guidance, 'you must keep your professional knowledge and skills up to date' which is why attending formal teaching sessions is vital. See the guidance here: http://www.gmc-uk.org/guidance/goodmedicalpractice/maintainperformance.asp

options: Tell the patient that you must inform the DVLA on his behalf
Explain to the patient that he cannot leave the surgery until he has arranged alternative transport home
Do nothing
Inform the next of kin
Allow him to leave the consultation room and then contact the DVLA
Explain the reasons for your decision
Discuss your decision with an experienced colleague
Inform the patient that it is his responsibility to contact the DVLA
questions:
You are a junior doctor working in a GP surgery. You see an elderly gentleman who complains of reduced vision. After examining him you provisionally diagnose him with age related macular degeneration and refer him to ophthalmology. You decide that it would be unsafe for him to drive in the meantime. He is unhappy about this decision. What do you do?

Select the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation
notes:
In the first instance, it is the patient's responsibility to inform the DVLA of changes to their health which may affect their ability to drive. From here the DVLA can give their recommendations. As a clinician it is your responsibility to tell the patient that they need to do this. As the patient is unhappy, you should ensure that he is fully aware of why you have decided he should not drive. This may make it more acceptable to him. Discussion with an experienced colleague is the next best option from the list. The GMC recommend doing this if you have any doubt whether or not the patient should be driving.

In the first instance it is not your responsibility to inform the DVLA for him. You may have to do this if he continues to ignore advice. The patient cannot be forced to stay at the surgery and so this is not correct but ideally they would arrange alternative transport home. The next of kin need not be informed at this stage, and you cannot inform the next of kin without permission from the patient. You should not be allowing the patient to drive even a short distance home in this situation. Your advice must remain as no driving until further notice.

title: General Medical Council: duties of a doctor
body:
Make the care of your patient your first concern

Protect and promote the health of patients and the public
  • Provide a good standard of practice and care
  • Keep your professional knowledge and skills up to date
  • Recognise and work within the limits of your competence
  • Work with colleagues in the ways that best serve patients' interests

Treat patients as individuals and respect their dignity
  • Treat patients politely and considerately
  • Respect patients' right to confidentiality

Work in partnership with patients
  • Listen to patients and respond to their concerns and preferences
  • Give patients the information they want or need in a way they can understand
  • Respect patients' right to reach decisions with you about their treatment and care
  • Support patients in caring for themselves to improve and maintain their health

Be honest and open and act with integrity
  • Act without delay if you have good reason to believe that you or a colleague may be putting patients at risk
  • Never discriminate unfairly against patients or colleagues
  • Never abuse your patients' trust in you or the public's trust in the profession.

options: Remind him of how stretched the NHS is
Advise him to contact PALS (Patient Advisory Liaison Service)
Go back and listen to his concerns after the ward round to see if you can resolve any issues
Ask him to make a formal complaint in writing
Give the patient a choice of being more respectful or transferring to a different ward
questions:
You are a ST1 doctor in medicine. During a ward round a patient who has been admitted following a stroke says he is not happy with a number of aspects of his treatment including the hospital food and lack of physiotherapy.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
When patients or their relatives feel that they have received inadequate care the first step is to try and achieve local resolution. Speaking to the health care professionals involved can often resolve any misunderstandings. If this does not resolve the issue then PALS should be contacted to try and help. If this still fails then a written complaint should be made to allow a formal response from the hospital.

All complaints should be dealt with seriously and on an individual basis. Whilst limited NHS resources will undoubtedly contribute to failings in care they should not be sighted in individual cases. Threatening the patient with removal to a different ward is the worst response.

options: Inform the GMC of his conduct
Decline and suggest he consults with his regular GP
Briefly ascertain any past medical history and advise him that taking ciprofloxacin is not normally recommended
Suggest he tries asking another doctor
Decline and remind him of the GMC prescribing guidance
questions:
A friend of yours who is a doctor asks you to prescribe him a course of ciprofloxacin as he is going to Goa on holiday in three days time.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
The GMC have the following to say on prescribing to people you know:
'Doctors should, wherever possible, avoid treating themselves or anyone with whom they have a close personal relationship and should be registered with a GP outside their family.'

Therefore the best option is to advise him to see his own GP. This is better than option E, where you are simply regurgitating GMC guidance, as it provides practical and sensible advice.

Getting into a discussion about his past medical history is problematic as it blurs the boundaries of being a doctor or a friend. Advising him to ask another doctor is a poor option as it just passes the problem on to another doctor.

Both D and A are poor options. The key question is whether a GMC referral is warranted:

The guidance goes into more detail about whether prescribing to a friend/colleague is likely to warrant a GMC referral:

When concerns are raised about a doctor self-prescribing or prescribing for those in a close personal relationship to the doctor, they are only likely to raise a question about the doctor's fitness to practise if there are aggravating features present which include:
  • a the prescribing is for controlled drugs; clearly this points to a serious underlying condition for which independent assessment and treatment is required.
  • b The prescribing is repeated; an isolated prescription for a non-controlled drug is very unlikely to reach the realistic prospect threshold. Repeat prescribing may call into question the adequacy of independent clinical review of the patient's condition.
  • c The prescribing is inappropriate; a prescription for an excessive dosage or overall quantity could point to fitness to practise issues.
  • d Other aggravating feature, such as false declarations for free prescriptions or prescribing in the names of others. Such probity issues must be investigated.

From the information given in the scenario, it doesn't seem that the doctor's request warrants an automatic GMC referral.

At ward rounds, your consultant Dr Smith changes the antibiotic she is taking as the infection is responding slowly. options: Discuss the case with the hospital legal team
Explore the daughters views in further detail
Immediately inform the registrar or consultant
Inform the daughter that this is a decision that will be made by the medical team
Transfer the patient back to the nursing home
Refer the patient to palliative care for end of life care
Refer the patient to a hospice
Assess the patient's capacity
questions:
You are the F2 doctor working in the acute medical unit. An 85-year-old male is admitted from a nursing home with abdominal pain and fever. He has advanced dementia and is bedbound with an extremely poor quality of life. You suspect that he has intra-abdominal sepsis. His daughter who has legal power of attorney for healthcare decisions calls the ward and states that she does not want her father to receive any life-prolonging treatment and would like him transferred back to the nursing home. You assess that he will die if he doesn't receive prompt treatment.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
The GMC guidance 'Decision-making when a patient lacks capacity' states that 'In Scotland, a welfare attorney or a court-appointed guardian may have the legal authority to make healthcare decisions on the patient's behalf. In England or Wales, this could be someone with lasting power of attorney, or a court-appointed deputy. Proxy decision-making is not currently available in Northern Ireland for these circumstances.'

It would firstly be essential to assess the patient's capacity. Although their advanced dementia likely renders them incapacitated it would be wrong to simply assume this. Following this, a senior doctor should double-check their capacity given the gravity of the situation.

This is a time-critical scenario. You should therefore immediately inform the registrar or consultant so that they can have a conversation with the daughter to explore her views in further detail. For example, the patient has advanced dementia and it may not be in their best interests to admit to the hospital for life-prolonging treatment. In most cases the proxy will be acting in the best interests of the patient and the medical team will be in agreement. Since complex decision-making is required in a time-critical manner, it would be best to inform a senior immediately so that they can lead further discussions.

If there was a disagreement between the proxy and the medical team then steps should be taken to resolve the matter, for example by holding a case meeting, getting a second opinion, and engaging in further discussion. Only as a last resort should the hospital legal team get involved.

As the daughter has power of attorney, she has the legal power to make a decision on behalf of her father, and it is, therefore, wrong to inform her that this is a decision that will be made by the medical team.

Once a decision has been made further discussions should take place with regards to the location of further care for the patient e.g. transferring the patient back to the nursing home or referring the patient to a hospice, but these should come later after the essential first steps are taken.

Referring the patient to palliative care for end-of-life care may be appropriate; however, in the first instance, a decision with regard to a treatment escalation plan needs to be determined by the appropriate steps above.

title: GMC: Treatment and care towards the end of life - Working with the principles and decision-making models
body:
There's an old aphorism in medicine sometimes attributed to Hippocrates: 'c'ure sometimes, treat often, comfort always'. This reminds us to think about goals of care. The end of life is a time when it is important to think ethically and communicate effectively about these goals.

Recognition that a patient is entering the end of life is the first step is determining the goals of care. We are often too slow to see the signs that death is near, and too slow to think that our interventions need to change in order to reflect this. Just because a patient cannot be cured does not mean they should not be treated or comforted.

Good palliative care at the end of life can make the difference between an agonising and emotionally traumatic death or one in comfort, quiet and relative dignity. Good clinical medicine and good ethical reasoning are needed to make sure this happens.

Key principles

The GMC lists key principles which should control decision-making at the end of life.

Equalities and human rights. Those at the end of life are owed the same quality of care as all patients, including with regard to dignity and confidentiality.

Presumption in favour of prolonging life. Any decision about potentially life-prolonging treatment should not be motivated by a desire to bring about a patient's death. There is also a general presumption to take all reasonable steps which can prolong life, though, depending on patient's wishes and doctors' clinical judgement, it may be considered appropriate to refrain from providing or withdraw a potentially life-prolonging intervention.

Presumption of capacity. The usual assumption that all adults have capacity until it has been shown they lack it applies to patients at the end of life.

Maximising capacity to make decisions. Capacity should be assessed for each relevant decision, and steps should be taken to support patients in doing so.

Overall benefit. If a patient lacks capacity, a decision in their overall benefit should be made.

A decision-making model for patients with capacity
  • Assess the patient's condition, understanding and views
  • Use your experience and clinical judgment to identify investigations and treatments clinically appropriate and likely to result in overall benefit for the patient. Explain these options, laying out their potential burdens, risks and benefits
  • Allow the patient to accept or refuse any of these options

What if a patient with capacity requests something clinically inappropriate?

Inquire into why the patient is making such a request, and clarify potential misunderstandings. If the patient maintains their clinically inappropriate request you are not obliged to fulfil it. You should explain why you do not think it is appropriate and allow the patient to exercise their right to a second opinion should they wish to do so.

A decision-making model for adults who lack capacity

There are some additional measure to take for adults who lack capacity:
  • Clearly identify which clinical decisions need to be made
  • Check if the patient has a legally binding advance decision
  • Find out if the patient has a legal proxy (NB: not all proxies are permitted to make medical decisions)
  • Take responsibility for deciding which treatment will provide overall benefit to the patient if there is no legal proxy, making sure to consult those close to the patient when doing so

When this stage is reached, the model for making a clinical decision is as follows:
  • Along with the patient's carer, assess the patient's condition, understanding and views
  • Along with evidence of the patient's views, use your experience and clinical judgement to identify investigations and treatments clinically appropriate and likely to result in overall benefit for the patient
  • If there is evidence of an advance decision, judge whether it is legally binding and/or applicable to the current circumstances
  • If it is, follow it. If it is not, include it as evidence in your assessment of a patient's wishes
  • If the patient has a legal proxy for clinical decisions, explain to them the different options along with their potential risks, benefits and burdens. Support the proxy's decision-making but do not pressurise it
  • If a proxy does not have legal power over clinical decisions their views should be considered, along with those of the rest of the healthcare team
  • In England and Wales, if there is no proxy or forthcoming other person to assist in the process, arrange for an Independent Mental Capacity Advocate to do so

What if there is disagreement between the proxy the medical team?

If the patient has a proxy to make clinical decisions and there is disagreement between the proxy and the medical team about what clinical decisions should be made steps should be taken to resolve the matter informally, for example by holding a case meeting, getting a second opinion, engaging in further discussion.

If all this fails, seek legal advice.

How do I make a decision in overall benefit?

Making a decision which is in the patient's overall benefit requires you to think both about clinically and ethically. It's not just a question of asking 'will this intervention work'? You also must ask: 'is it the right thing for this patient under these circumstances?'

What might be routine in other circumstances might be inappropriate if a patient is in extremis, for example because the intervention has an unreasonably small prospect of changing management and benefiting the patient. Fluid resuscitation might be basic protocol in other cases, but if a patient is lying on their death bed, it is unclear that they will derive a benefit from intravenous cannulation and a fluid bolus (subcutaneous fluids, however, might be appropriate).

Some questions to ask:
  • What is the aim of this procedure under these circumstances?
  • Does this procedure benefit the patient?
  • Is this aim appropriate to the goals of care?
  • Are these goals better served by other interventions?

NB: these questions are all about whether the intervention is worthwhile, not whether prolonging life of a given patient is worthwhile. The decision to refrain from intervening or withdrawing an intervention is best made on the basis of the proportionality of the intervention itself and not based on a judgement upon the value of the life it aims to sustain.

Putting this in to practice: DNACPR

Decisions to not attempt cardiopulmonary resuscitation illustrate the principles laid out in this guidance. When broaching this subject with patients/proxies it is important to communicate clearly the potential risks, benefits and harms. You need to assess the patient's clinical condition carefully as well as their own views. Then you need to lay before them the different options explaining the relevant risks etc. If you are satisfied that the patient understands this but still wishes to be resuscitated, it is important to explore this further. However, ultimately, the patient's wish cannot compel you to engage in CPR if, in your considered professional judgement, it is not appropriate.

Note, however, that a DNACPR order is not a licence for neglect or an excuse to stop all treatment. A patient may 'be DNACPR' but intravenous antibiotics might still be appropriate for them, for example. A DNACPR is only one clinical decision: the decisions that CPR would be inappropriate. It says nothing about other ceilings of care.

General pointers

Good communication'at a time of life which is fraught with emotion and stress poor communication and misunderstanding can only hinder care.

Plan ahead'failing to think about the end of life can leave patients and medical teams unprepared. Don't be blindsided by a deteriorating patient. Keep an eye out for the signs of decline and initiate the important discussions with the patient, relatives and colleagues.

Uncertainty'there is a lot of uncertainty around death. Help relatives deal with this by explaining what their relative is experiencing and what your plan is.

Review decisions'sometimes, a patient's condition will change unexpectedly. Be ready to reconsider previous decisions in light of this.

Know the law'be familiar with the laws relevant to your jurisdiction concerning capacity, advanced decisions etc.

Think ethically'just like it is important to reason from basic principles to conclusions in clinical medicine, so it is important to reason ethically through difficult decisions.

options: Apologise to the patient
Explain to the patient what has happened
Explain to the blood bank what has happened
Take responsibility for the situation and admit that the blame lies with you as the doctor
Gain the patient's consent to repeat the sample
Acknowledge that the patient has suffered enough and bleeding her can wait until tomorrow
Inform your registrar of the mistake and ask for advice
Do nothing
questions:
You are a junior doctor working in colorectal surgery. You have been informed that the phlebotomists have taken the blood of a patient which has now haemolysed and the results cannot be used. This patient is notoriously terrified of needles and hence difficult to bleed. You are monitoring her haemoglobin post-transfusion. What do you do?

Select the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation
notes:
The GMC recommend the following when things go wrong: offering an apology to the patient, putting the situation right (in this case, repeating the sample) and explaining what has happened and the short and long-term implications of the mistake.

Explaining to the blood bank what has happened is unlikely to make a difference in this situation. If a sample has haemolysed there is little that can be done short of retaking the sample either immediately or at a later date if it is not urgent. The blame for what has happened neither rests on you and nor do you have to justify what has happened. Apologising is enough. In some situations, waiting until tomorrow to bleed a patient again may be appropriate however if a patient has required a blood transfusion it seems likely that the sample the following day will be needed. Another reasonable answer would be to ask your SHO for advice, but the correct answers are more in line with GMC guidance. Doing nothing will not help to resolve the situation and the patient may suffer as a consequence.

You are a junior doctor working in colorectal surgery. You have been informed that the phlebotomists have taken the blood of a patient which has now haemolysed and the results cannot be used. This patient is notoriously terrified of needles and hence difficult to bleed. You are monitoring her haemoglobin post-transfusion. What do you do?

Select the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation

The GMC recommend the following when things go wrong: offering an apology to the patient, putting the situation right (in this case, repeating the sample) and explaining what has happened and the short and long-term implications of the mistake.

title: Duty of candour
body:
All healthcare professionals must be honest when something has gone wrong. They must:
  • Tell the patient when something has gone wrong
  • Apologise to the patient (or carer or family member where appropriate)
  • Offer an appropriate resolution
  • Explain the potential short and long-term effects of the error

Important to note:
  • Saying sorry is not an admission of legal liability
  • The patient has a right to receive an apology from 'the most appropriate team member' - this will usually be the lead or accountable clinician
  • The process for reporting adverse incidents and near misses varies between different health organisations: you must follow your own organisations policy
  • The National Report d scheme

Cancel plans with your friend at the last minute and cover for the doctor
Shout that it is not your fault she is late and this is unacceptable but still cover for her
Try and find another doctor to cover for her and if you fail to find one, leave
Ring your friend and tell her that you will be late and cover for the doctor
questions:
You are about to finish your shift ready to meet a friend for dinner when the doctor taking over from you rings to inform you she is running half hour late. She asks if you will cover her until she arrives.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
This question tests your ability to prioritise between work and social life without compromising patient care.

The best option in this question is E. Although you had made alternative plans, if you leave before your fellow doctor arrives, patient care will be compromised. option E shows you took the initiative to plan on the job and take the time to push back your plans.

As a doctor, you need to be able to balance your work life balance. A better option to cancelling the plans would be to ring the friend and see if she could see you later. This way patient care is not compromised for you leaving and you also get to see your friend.

It may not be the doctor's fault that they are late and even so, you work together as a team and should be able to support one another. shouting at her will not achieve anything and hence is lower ranked than E and B.

The worst options are D and A. By leaving the ward you compromise the care of the patient. D ranks higher than A as it shows you at least attempted to try and find cover.

options: Ask security to restrain her father when he arrives
Do not allow her father into the room with her
Ask her father about the cigarette burns
Take a history from her and separately from her father to see if there are inconsistencies
Arrange a family meeting with the multidisciplinary team (MDT)
Contact the police
Call her father and inform him of the allegations
Treat her medical problems but do not get involved in her personal matters
Inform the children's safeguarding team
Inform the General Medical Council (GMC)
questions:
You are a registrar in a busy Emergency Department and are caring for a 14-year-old girl brought in for a paracetamol overdose. While examining her, you notice marks resembling cigarette burns on her arms. On questioning, she reports that these are indeed cigarette burns left by her father. You are aware that her father is on his way to the department.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
This question relates to the doctor's duty when identifying that a child may be subject to abuse from their parent.

The General Medical Council (GMC) is clear that when an accusation of physical abuse has been made, efforts must be made to keep the child separate from the person accused until an investigation has taken place. As such, her father should not be allowed in the room with her (B).

The children's safeguarding team and police (F and I) need to be promptly contacted. This child has accused their caregiver of physical abuse and this is a criminal matter that needs to be dealt with by the police.

Asking security to restrain the father on his arrival (A) is an overreaction based on the clinical vignette. They are not trained for this type of situation and there is no reason to think that he will act violently. If he does arrive and act violently then security may be involved.

Asking her father about the cigarette burns (C) is the job of the police who need to investigate the matter, this is not your job as the child's doctor. This is also why taking a history from her and her father is not an appropriate action.

Family meetings (E) have a place within clinical practice, for example, when family members do not agree the clinical teams' approach to their family member's care. It is inappropriate to hold a family meeting in this case, this is a criminal matter that needs to be dealt with by the police.

There is no reason for you to call her father and inform him of the allegations (G). Your focus is on the care of your patient. This is also a sensitive matter and is best discussed in person if it comes to it.

Whilst treating the patient's medical problems is important, ignoring the issue of physical abuse is a flagrant violation of your professional duty as a doctor and may result in further harm being done to the child upon their discharge (H).

The GMC (J) have no jurisdiction in this matter, they investigate concerns about doctors. This is a police matter.

title: GMC: Protecting children and young people - Identifying those at risk of, or suffering, abuse or neglect
body:
The GMC produces guidance for all doctors on a variety of different important issues. This article relates to the specific guidance on protecting children and young people, including how to identify those at risk of, or suffering, from abuse or neglect.

Roles of all doctors
  • You must take into account the safety and welfare of children and young people, regardless of whether you routinely treat them. This means that you must determine the safety of any children or young people that your patients may come into contact with if they could be a risk to them. For example, a GP may be seeing a patient for their alcohol dependency. As well as considering the patient's physical and mental health, you must consider the social care needed at home and the children that may be at home. There may be no need for concern, however there is the potential in this situation for vulnerable children in the home that may need flagging to the relevant authorities, situation dependent.
  • You must have adequate knowledge of the signs and risk factors (e.g. parents that have mental health issues, drug or alcohol dependence, the presence of domestic violence and living in a socially deprived area) linked to child abuse to ensure you can identify at-risk children and young people. The risk factors mentioned previously are not always present in cases of abuse, and the presence of them does not mean that abuse is taking place. It is important to be aware that signs of abuse can be subtle and can affect children from any background.
  • You should attempt to identify signs of abuse as early as possible, this includes preempting neglectful situations by identifying parents or guardians that may need extra help, in whatever form this may be. If it is appropriate for you to provide support, then you must take the necessary actions to put this in place. If it is not your role, then refer the family to the local authority children's services so that they can access help.
  • As well as identifying the at-risk child or young person, you need to be aware of the correct protocols for safeguarding children. This often includes contacting the appropriate safeguarding paediatrician, social services and other healthcare/ social professionals involved in the child's care. It is important to notify the parents/ guardians of your referral if appropriate and answer any questions they may have. You should document clearly your concerns and the actions you have taken. You should be confident in being able to appropriately implement these when necessary. You should be aware of your lead clinician's contact details to gain invaluable advice in navigating these often complex situations
  • If you are concerned about a child or young person, or if a concern is raised to you, it is your obligation and duty as a doctor to act on these worries

Roles of doctors who work with children or young people
  • If a part of your job role involves you working with children or young people, you are required to have the appropriate skills to identify patients that have been abused or neglected, and the subsequent ability to take appropriate actions immediately. This does not apply solely to specialties that you might traditionally associate as involving the treatment of children. It encompasses almost all medical careers in one way or another.
  • Not only must you be actively considering abuse and neglect as a differential diagnosis for certain patients, you must also consider alternative diagnoses that could also provide an explanation for the symptoms. For example, a child presenting with recurrent fractures following several minimal impact injuries immediately rings alarm bells. Here you should consider child abuse as a potential cause. However, it is also important to consider other conditions that might explain this odd presentation, for example it could be osteogenesis imperfecta (a congenital connective tissue disease causing 'brittle bones')
  • Whilst treating patients that you suspect may have been abused or neglected, you must ensure that these children receive the clinical support and care necessary, and that this does not suffer due to the complicated and time consuming nature of child protection protocols
  • Where possible, you should support parents or guardians in providing a caring and supportive home for children, an important part of this being the ability to signpost to local services and voluntary groups that may be of use. Even if parents are not currently providing the adequate emotional and physical care for their children, it does not mean that this cannot be improved with help. Sometimes, all that's needed is some encouragement and advice. Referring parents or guardians for additional support does not mean that they are not good parents, and it is important to talk through any queries they may have regarding your referral. Of course, if you suspect abuse then this is a more urgent matter and more drastic intervention is necessary.
  • Cultural practices in terms of raising children can be vastly different from family to family. Parents and guardians have the freedom to bring up their child as they choose, within reason. The line between abuse or neglect and religious or cultural practices that don't align with your personal view can sometimes be blurred. You should ensure that you are well aware of the beliefs of different cultural and religious groups to ensure that you are clear on what is appropriate and in line with a certain culture, and what is excessive and abusive. In cases where you are unsure of where the boundary lies between cultural or religious practice and neglect, you can consult a member of the relevant group to advise on usual practice and whether the questioned behaviour is fitting and appropriate to the culture/ religion. The hospital chaplaincy is a good place to start regarding religious matters, however do not delay in referring to the local safeguarding officer if you are in doubt as they will often have a superior knowledge of religious/ cultural customs.
  • Similarly, you must ensure that your own cultural or religious background does not affect your decision making in these situations. Personal views should not play a role in making these safeguarding decisions. If in doubt, seek advice from your local safeguarding officer, paediatrician on call or a professional body that has experience in working with children
  • It is important to notify the parents or guardians of your concerns. If, despite discussing your concerns, you are still unsure of what to do, you should escalate the situation to ensure that no neglected or abused patients slip through the net
  • If you are a lead clinician regularly involved in the care of children or young people, you should ensure that your juniors are aware of the help and advice that you can offer when it comes to these difficult situations. Your contact details should be handed out so that people can promptly get in contact when needed. Often junior clinicians are unsure of how to deal with a situation involving an abused/ neglected child. They may not feel confident identifying the red flags and dealing with the parents/ guardians in a non-accusatory manner. If you are a clinician that regularly deals with this, putting on a short teaching session surrounding these issues may be of benefit

Summary

All doctors should be aware of the following:

  • the risk factors for abuse or neglect and how to identify an at-risk child
  • that your adult patients may have a negative impact on the children in their life. For example, it is important not to send the drunk, violent man in the ED department home to his three children aged under five. In this situation, you have to look at the wider picture and consider the safety of the children involved
  • that it is important to remain open-minded and explore all possibilities for the cause of suspicious symptoms
  • that you should seek advice from a senior colleague if you are unsure of whether to refer a young child for abuse/ neglect

Remember, if in doubt always get a senior opinion, and these guidelines are online to consult at any time!
